extracted_concepts.definition: A d20 roll, modified by ability and proficiency, used to determine if an attack hits its target.

rule_logic.premise: A creature attempts to hit a target with an attack
rule_logic.implication: Roll a d20 and add relevant modifiers. If the total equals or exceeds the target's Armor Class (AC), the attack hits.
rule_logic.description_text: To make an attack roll, roll a d20 and add the appropriate modifiers. If the total of the roll plus modifiers equals or exceeds the target’s Armor Class (AC), the attack hits.

extracted_concepts.definition: Bonuses added to an attack roll, typically consisting of an ability modifier and proficiency bonus.

rule_logic.premise: Determining the bonus for an attack roll
rule_logic.implication: Add the relevant ability modifier (Strength for melee, Dexterity for ranged, or specific ability for other attacks) AND the creature's proficiency bonus (if proficient with the weapon/attack).
rule_logic.description_text: When a creature makes an attack, the attack roll is modified by its ability score modifier (Strength for melee attacks, Dexterity for ranged attacks) and its proficiency bonus (if it is proficient with the weapon or attack).

extracted_concepts.definition: An exceptionally precise attack roll that automatically hits and causes additional damage.

rule_logic.premise: An attack roll results in a natural 20
rule_logic.implication: The attack automatically hits, and you roll extra dice for the attack's damage against the target.
rule_logic.description_text: If the d20 roll for an attack is a 20, the attack hits regardless of any modifiers or the target’s AC. This is called a critical hit, which means you roll extra dice for the attack’s damage against the target.

extracted_concepts.definition: An exceptionally poor attack roll that misses, regardless of modifiers or target AC.

rule_logic.premise: An attack roll results in a natural 1
rule_logic.implication: The attack automatically misses, regardless of any modifiers or the target’s AC.
rule_logic.description_text: If the d20 roll for an attack is a 1, the attack misses regardless of any modifiers or the target’s AC.

extracted_concepts.definition: An action that is characterized by making an attack roll.

rule_logic.premise: An action involves making an attack roll
rule_logic.implication: The action counts as an attack
rule_logic.description_text: If there's ever any question whether something you're doing counts as an attack, the rule is simple: if you're making an attack roll, you're making an attack.
related_search_terms: does this count as an attack

extracted_concepts.definition: The initial step of an attack, where the attacker selects a valid recipient for the attack.

rule_logic.premise: Initiating an attack
rule_logic.implication: Choose one target (creature, object, or location) within the attack's range
rule_logic.description_text: 1. Choose a target. Pick a target within your attack's range: a creature, an object, or a location.

extracted_concepts.definition: The second step of an attack, where the Dungeon Master identifies and applies any relevant bonuses or penalties to the attack roll.

rule_logic.premise: After choosing a target for an attack
rule_logic.implication: The GM determines applicable modifiers: cover status of the target, advantage or disadvantage for the attacker, and any bonuses/penalties from spells, special abilities, or other effects
rule_logic.description_text: 2. Determine modifiers. The GM determines whether the target has cover and whether you have advantage or disadvantage against the target. In addition, spells, special abilities, and other effects can apply penalties or bonuses to your attack roll.

extracted_concepts.definition: The final step of an attack, where the attack roll is made and the consequences of a hit or miss are determined.

rule_logic.premise: After determining modifiers for an attack
rule_logic.implication: Make an attack roll. IF the attack hits THEN roll damage, UNLESS specific attack rules state otherwise. Special effects may also apply either in addition to or instead of damage.
exceptions: Particular attack rules specify otherwise for damage
rule_logic.description_text: 3. Resolve the attack. You make the attack roll. On a hit, you roll damage, unless the particular attack has rules that specify otherwise. Some attacks cause special effects in addition to or instead of damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: A d20 roll plus modifiers used to determine if an attack successfully hits its target's Armor Class (AC).

rule_logic.premise: An attack is made
rule_logic.implication: Roll a d20 + appropriate modifiers. If total >= target's AC, the attack hits. Otherwise, it misses.
rule_logic.description_text: When you make an attack, your attack roll determines whether the attack hits or misses. To make an attack roll, roll a d20 and add the appropriate modifiers. If the total of the roll plus modifiers equals or exceeds the target's Armor Class (AC), the attack hits.

extracted_concepts.definition: The default ability modifier used when making a melee weapon attack.

rule_logic.premise: Character makes a melee weapon attack
rule_logic.implication: Add Strength modifier to the attack roll
rule_logic.description_text: The ability modifier used for a melee weapon attack is Strength.

extracted_concepts.definition: The default ability modifier used when making a ranged weapon attack.

rule_logic.premise: Character makes a ranged weapon attack
rule_logic.implication: Add Dexterity modifier to the attack roll
exceptions: Weapons with the thrown property (may use Strength instead of Dexterity)
rule_logic.description_text: The ability modifier used for a ranged weapon attack is Dexterity.

extracted_concepts.concept_name: Finesse or Thrown Weapon (Ability Modifier Exception)
extracted_concepts.definition: Weapons with the finesse or thrown property allow for exceptions to the standard ability modifier rules for weapon attacks.

rule_logic.premise: A weapon has the finesse OR thrown property
rule_logic.implication: The standard rule for determining the ability modifier (Strength for melee, Dexterity for ranged) is overridden/modified.
rule_logic.description_text: Weapons that have the finesse or thrown property break this rule.

extracted_concepts.definition: The ability modifier added to an attack roll for a spell, which depends on the caster's spellcasting ability.

rule_logic.premise: Character casts a spell that requires an attack roll
rule_logic.implication: Add the spellcaster's spellcasting ability modifier to the attack roll
rule_logic.description_text: Some spells also require an attack roll. The ability modifier used for a spell attack depends on the spellcasting ability of the spellcaster.

extracted_concepts.definition: An additional bonus added to attack rolls when using a weapon with which the attacker is proficient.

rule_logic.premise: Character makes an attack using a weapon with which they have proficiency
rule_logic.implication: Add proficiency bonus to the attack roll
rule_logic.description_text: You add your proficiency bonus to your attack roll when you attack using a weapon with which you have proficiency
related_search_terms: what is proficiency bonus for weapons

extracted_concepts.definition: An additional bonus added to all spell attack rolls.

rule_logic.premise: Character makes an attack with a spell
rule_logic.implication: Add proficiency bonus to the attack roll
rule_logic.description_text: as well as when you attack with a spell.

extracted_concepts.definition: Rolling a 20 on the d20 for an attack roll, resulting in an automatic hit and a critical hit.

rule_logic.premise: The d20 roll for an attack is a 20
rule_logic.implication: The attack hits regardless of any modifiers or the target's AC. This is a critical hit.
rule_logic.description_text: If the d20 roll for an attack is a 20, the attack hits regardless of any modifiers or the target's AC. This is called a critical hit, which is explained later in this chapter.

extracted_concepts.definition: Rolling a 1 on the d20 for an attack roll, resulting in an automatic miss.

rule_logic.premise: The d20 roll for an attack is a 1
rule_logic.implication: The attack misses regardless of any modifiers or the target's AC.
rule_logic.description_text: If the d20 roll for an attack is a 1, the attack misses regardless of any modifiers or the target's AC.

extracted_concepts.definition: Describes the conditions and consequences when a creature attempts to attack a target it cannot perceive.

rule_logic.premise: Attacker targets a creature it cannot see
rule_logic.implication: Attacker has disadvantage on the attack roll. IF target is not in the exact location targeted, THEN attack automatically misses.
rule_logic.description_text: When you attack a target that you can't see, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. This is true whether you're guessing the target's location or you're targeting a creature you can hear but not see. If the target isn't in the location you targeted, you automatically miss, but the GM typically just says that the attack missed, not whether you guessed the target's location correctly.

extracted_concepts.definition: Describes the benefit an attacker gains when its target cannot see it.

rule_logic.premise: Creature makes an attack roll AND its target cannot see it
rule_logic.implication: Creature has advantage on attack rolls against that target
rule_logic.description_text: When a creature can't see you, you have advantage on attack rolls against it.

extracted_concepts.definition: Describes the consequence of making an attack while hidden, specifically regarding the revelation of one's location.

rule_logic.premise: Creature is hidden (both unseen AND unheard) AND makes an attack (regardless of hit or miss)
rule_logic.implication: Creature gives away its location
rule_logic.description_text: If you are hidden-both unseen and unheard-when you make an attack, you give away your location when the attack hits or misses.

extracted_concepts.definition: An attack that involves sending projectiles, spells, or other effects to strike a foe at a distance.

rule_logic.premise: You use a bow, crossbow, handaxe, monster ability, or specific spell to strike a foe at a distance
rule_logic.implication: This action is classified as a Ranged Attack
rule_logic.description_text: When you make a ranged attack, you fire a bow or a crossbow, hurl a handaxe, or otherwise send projectiles to strike a foe at a distance. A monster might shoot spines from its tail. Many spells also involve making a ranged attack.

extracted_concepts.definition: The maximum distance within which a ranged attack can successfully target a creature.

rule_logic.premise: You make a ranged attack
rule_logic.implication: You can only target creatures within the specified range for that attack
rule_logic.description_text: You can make ranged attacks only against targets within a specified range.

extracted_concepts.definition: A ranged attack (typically a spell) that defines a single maximum distance as its range.

rule_logic.premise: A ranged attack (e.g., a spell) has a single specified range
rule_logic.implication: You cannot attack a target beyond this specified range
rule_logic.description_text: If a ranged attack, such as one made with a spell, has a single range, you can't attack a target beyond this range.

extracted_concepts.definition: The smaller of two specified ranges for certain ranged weapons, indicating the optimal distance for an attack without penalty.

rule_logic.premise: A ranged attack is made with a weapon (e.g., longbow, shortbow) that has two ranges AND the target is within the smaller number (normal range)
rule_logic.implication: The attack roll is made without disadvantage due to range
rule_logic.description_text: Some ranged attacks, such as those made with a longbow or a shortbow, have two ranges. The smaller number is the normal range...

extracted_concepts.definition: The larger of two specified ranges for certain ranged weapons, indicating the maximum possible distance for an attack, typically with disadvantage.

rule_logic.premise: A ranged attack is made with a weapon (e.g., longbow, shortbow) that has two ranges AND the target is beyond normal range but within long range
rule_logic.implication: Your attack roll has disadvantage
rule_logic.description_text: Some ranged attacks, such as those made with a longbow or a shortbow, have two ranges. The smaller number is the normal range, and the larger number is the long range. Your attack roll has disadvantage when your target is beyond normal range, and you can't attack a target beyond the long range.
related_search_terms: can I shoot beyond long range

extracted_concepts.definition: A condition causing disadvantage on ranged attack rolls when the attacker is in close proximity to a hostile, un-incapacitated, and aware creature.

rule_logic.premise: You make a ranged attack (with a weapon, spell, or other means) AND you are within 5 feet of a hostile creature AND that hostile creature can see you AND that hostile creature is not incapacitated
rule_logic.implication: You have disadvantage on the attack roll
rule_logic.description_text: Aiming a ranged attack is more difficult when a foe is next to you. When you make a ranged attack with a weapon, a spell, or some other means, you have disadvantage on the attack roll if you are within 5 feet of a hostile creature who can see you and who isn't incapacitated.

extracted_concepts.definition: An attack made in hand-to-hand combat against a foe within one's reach, typically using a handheld weapon or body part.

rule_logic.premise: You want to attack a foe in hand-to-hand combat within your reach
rule_logic.implication: You perform a melee attack
rule_logic.description_text: Used in hand-to-hand combat, a melee attack allows you to attack a foe within your reach. A melee attack typically uses a handheld weapon such as a sword, a warhammer, or an axe. A typical monster makes a melee attack when it strikes with its claws, horns, teeth, tentacles, or other body part. A few spells also involve making a melee attack.

extracted_concepts.definition: The maximum distance from which a creature can make a melee attack.

rule_logic.premise: A creature makes a melee attack AND no specific reach is noted in its description
rule_logic.implication: The creature has a 5-foot reach and can attack targets within 5 feet of it
exceptions: Certain creatures (typically those larger than Medium) have melee attacks with a greater reach than 5 feet, as noted in their descriptions.
rule_logic.description_text: Most creatures have a 5-foot reach and can thus attack targets within 5 feet of them when making a melee attack. Certain creatures (typically those larger than Medium) have melee attacks with a greater reach than 5 feet, as noted in their descriptions.

extracted_concepts.definition: A special type of melee attack made without a weapon, using a punch, kick, head-butt, or similar forceful blow.

rule_logic.premise: You use an Attack action AND choose to make an unarmed strike instead of a weapon attack
rule_logic.implication: On a hit, deal 1 + Strength modifier bludgeoning damage. You are proficient with your unarmed strikes. Unarmed strikes do not count as weapons.
rule_logic.description_text: Instead of using a weapon to make a melee weapon attack, you can use an unarmed strike: a punch, kick, head-butt, or similar forceful blow (none of which count as weapons). On a hit, an unarmed strike deals bludgeoning damage equal to 1 + your Strength modifier. You are proficient with your unarmed strikes.

extracted_concepts.definition: A special melee attack made in response to a hostile creature moving out of one's reach.

rule_logic.premise: A hostile creature that you can see moves out of your reach AND you have your reaction available
rule_logic.implication: You can use your reaction to make one melee attack against the provoking creature. The attack occurs right before the creature leaves your reach.
rule_logic.description_text: You can make an opportunity attack when a hostile creature that you can see moves out of your reach. To make the opportunity attack, you use your reaction to make one melee attack against the provoking creature. The attack occurs right before the creature leaves your reach.

extracted_concepts.definition: Methods by which a creature can move without triggering an opportunity attack.

rule_logic.premise: A creature moves out of an enemy's reach
rule_logic.implication: No opportunity attack is provoked IF the creature takes the Disengage action OR teleports OR is moved by an external force (not using its movement, action, or reaction).
exceptions: Being moved by an external force (not own movement, action, reaction).
rule_logic.description_text: You can avoid provoking an opportunity attack by taking the Disengage action. You also don't provoke an opportunity attack when you teleport or when someone or something moves you without using your movement, action, or reaction. For example, you don't provoke an opportunity attack if an explosion hurls you out of a foe's reach or if gravity causes you to fall past an enemy.

extracted_concepts.definition: A combat style allowing a creature to make an additional attack with a second light melee weapon as a bonus action.

rule_logic.premise: You take the Attack action AND attack with a light melee weapon held in one hand AND you are holding a different light melee weapon in the other hand
rule_logic.implication: You can use a bonus action to attack with the light melee weapon in your other hand. You do not add your ability modifier to the damage of this bonus attack, unless the modifier is negative.
exceptions: Ability modifier is NOT added to bonus attack damage, unless the modifier is negative.
rule_logic.description_text: When you take the Attack action and attack with a light melee weapon that you're holding in one hand, you can use a bonus action to attack with a different light melee weapon that you're holding in the other hand. You don't add your ability modifier to the damage of the bonus attack, unless that modifier is negative.

extracted_concepts.definition: Variation of two-weapon fighting where a weapon with the thrown property can be thrown instead of used in melee for the bonus action attack.

rule_logic.premise: You are performing a two-weapon fighting bonus action attack AND either of the light melee weapons has the thrown property
rule_logic.implication: You can throw the weapon instead of making a melee attack with it.
rule_logic.description_text: If either weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon, instead of making a melee attack with it.

extracted_concepts.definition: Challenges in battle where the prowess of two foes is pitted against each other, typically resolved by opposed ability checks.

rule_logic.premise: Battle involves pitting your prowess against that of your foe
rule_logic.implication: This is represented by a contest, often requiring an action and resolved by opposed ability checks.
rule_logic.description_text: Battle often involves pitting your prowess against that of your foe. Such a challenge is represented by a contest. This section includes the most common contests that require an action in combat: grappling and shoving a creature. The GM can use these contests as models for improvising others.

extracted_concepts.definition: A special melee attack used to grab and wrestle a creature, often resulting in the grappled condition.

rule_logic.premise: You take the Attack action AND choose to make a special melee attack to grapple a creature AND the target is no more than one size larger than you AND the target is within your reach AND you have at least one free hand
rule_logic.implication: You make a Strength (Athletics) check, contested by the target's Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. If you succeed, the target is subjected to the grappled condition. This replaces one of your attacks if you have multiple attacks.
rule_logic.description_text: When you want to grab a creature or wrestle with it, you can use the Attack action to make a special melee attack, a grapple. If you're able to make multiple attacks with the Attack action, this attack replaces one of them. The target of your grapple must be no more than one size larger than you and must be within your reach. Using at least one free hand, you try to seize the target by making a grapple check instead of an attack roll: a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the target's Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check (the target chooses the ability to use). If you succeed, you subject the target to the grappled condition (see appendix PH-A). The condition specifies the things that end it, and you can release the target whenever you like (no action required).

extracted_concepts.definition: The act of voluntarily ending the grappled condition on a creature you are grappling.

rule_logic.premise: You are grappling a target
rule_logic.implication: You can release the target whenever you like, and no action is required.
rule_logic.description_text: you can release the target whenever you like (no action required).

extracted_concepts.definition: The process by which a grappled creature can free itself from the grappled condition.

rule_logic.premise: A creature is subjected to the grappled condition AND uses its action to attempt to escape
rule_logic.implication: The grappled creature must succeed on a Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check contested by the grappler's Strength (Athletics) check. If successful, the grappled condition ends.
rule_logic.description_text: A grappled creature can use its action to escape. To do so, it must succeed on a Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check contested by your Strength (Athletics) check.

extracted_concepts.definition: Rules for moving while simultaneously dragging or carrying a grappled creature.

rule_logic.premise: You are grappling a creature AND you move
rule_logic.implication: You can drag or carry the grappled creature with you. Your speed is halved, unless the creature is two or more sizes smaller than you.
exceptions: Speed is NOT halved if the grappled creature is two or more sizes smaller than you.
rule_logic.description_text: When you move, you can drag or carry the grappled creature with you, but your speed is halved, unless the creature is two or more sizes smaller than you.

extracted_concepts.definition: A special melee attack used to knock a creature prone or push it away.

rule_logic.premise: You take the Attack action AND choose to make a special melee attack to shove a creature AND the target is no more than one size larger than you AND the target is within your reach
rule_logic.implication: You make a Strength (Athletics) check, contested by the target's Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. If you win the contest, you either knock the target prone OR push it 5 feet away from you. This replaces one of your attacks if you have multiple attacks.
rule_logic.description_text: Using the Attack action, you can make a special melee attack to shove a creature, either to knock it prone or push it 5 feet away from you. If you're able to make multiple attacks with the Attack action, this attack replaces one of them. The target must be no more than one size larger than you and must be within your reach. Instead of making an attack roll, you make a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the target's Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check (the target chooses the ability to use). If you win the contest, you either knock the target prone or push it 5 feet away from you.
